block.p: For nearly two decades, Peter Glaser (''Power From Space Is Pollution Free,'' Oct. 1) has tried to convince the energy community that we should capture solar energy in space and beam space power back to terra firma. His scheme has never caught hold for two fundamental reasons:

He has not shown that the marginal cost of collecting energy in space, compared with ground based systems, repays the marginal cost. And public and private leaders have grown increasingly wary of large-scale energy schemes, particularly those that rely on large inputs and guarantees from the public.

The question is simple: Is energy the justification for a space program, or vice versa? With the growing evidence of climate change, better to get on with more mundane ways of generating clean energy, particularly using amorphous silicon photovoltaic cells for electricity and hydrogen, energy-efficiency, and perhaps a new kind of nuclear fission (or fusion that works), rather than the pie-in-the-sky Mr. Glaser has proposed for so long. DR. LEE SCHIPPER Co-leader International Energy Studies Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory Berkely, Calif., Oct. 2.
